questions.text: Name the structure passing through the foramen marked in the image below.

choices.text: Second division of the fifth cranial nerve
Third division of the fifth cranial nerve

questions.solution:
Second (maxillary) division of the fifth cranial nerve passes through the Foramen rotundum (foramen marked in the image).

OTHER OPTIONS:

Third division (mandibular) of the fifth cranial nerve passes through the Foramen ovale along with accessory meningeal artery.

Vidian Nerve (also known as Nerve to Pterygoid Canal) passes through the Pterygoid Canal.

The image shows the sphenoid bone. It lies in the base of the skull between the frontal, temporal, and occipital bones. It consists of a central body, paired greater and lesser wings that are spread laterally from the body, and two pterygoid processes that project downwards from the junction of the body and the greater wings.

The foramen rotundum lies superolateral to the pterygoid canal, in the greater wing of the sphenoid. It transmits the maxillary nerve.

The pterygoid canal (also called, vidian canal) is a passage in the sphenoid bone, located inferomedial to the foramen rotundum. It transmits the vidian artery, vidian vein, and the vidian nerve.

Related Pearl: Structures passing through skull foramina

Opening Transmits
Optic canal Optic nerves and ophthalmic arteries
Superior orbital fissure First (orbital) division of the fifth, and the third, fourth and sixth cranial nerves, superior orbital
vein and a branch of the middle meningeal artery
Inferior orbital fissure Infraorbital nerve and infraorbital artery and the inferior ophthalmic veins
Foramen rotundum Second (maxillary) division of the fifth cranial nerve
Foramen ovale Third (mandibular) division of the fifth cranial nerve and the accessory meningeal artery
Foramen spinosum The middle meningeal artery
Foramen lacerum No large structure completely traverses through it.
Carotid canal Internal carotid artery.
Jugular foramen Inferior Petrosal sinus, Cranial nerves IX,X & XI and Sigmoid Sinus that continues as IJV as it passes the foramen.
Hypoglossal canal Twelfth (hypoglossal) cranial nerve
Foramen magnum

Medulla oblongata, along vertebral and spinal arteries and veins, and the spinal root of the eleventh cranial nerve

questions.text:
Consider the following statements about CCK (Cholecystokinin) and choose the correct statement(s).

1. Secreted by I cells of duodenum and jejunum.

2. It inhibits gastric emptying.

3. It inhibits pancreatic enzyme secretion.

4. It enhances small intestinal motility.
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 2 and 4 are correct. CCK stimulates pancreatic enzyme secretion (not inihibits). Hence, Statement 3 is false.

Cholecystokinin is secreted by the I cells of the duodenal and jejunal mucosa in response to monoglycerides, fatty acids and amino acids.

Primary functions:

  • Stimulation of pancreatic enzyme secretion.
  • Contraction of the gallbladder.
  • Relaxation of the sphincter of Oddi.

Other functions:

  • Augmentation of the action of secretin in producing alkaline pancreatic juice.
  • Inhibition of gastric emptying.
  • Trophic effect on the pancreas.
  • Increases the synthesis of enterokinase
  • It enhances the motility of the small intestine and colon.
  • Along with secretin, it augments the contraction of the pyloric sphincter and thus preventing the reflux of duodenal contents into the stomach.
  • It promotes satiety.

Related Pearl: Source and actions of gastrointestinal hormones

questions.text:
A 12 year old female patient presented with acute symptoms of abdominal and flank pain, nausea, dark red urine, fevers and chills following  a viral upper respiratory tract infection.  A direct antiglobulin test was positive for anti-C3d and negative for IgM. The cold agglutinin titer was negative (<2). A Donath Landsteiner antibody test against p antigen was positive. 
What is the most probable diagnosis of this case?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is Cold hemolysin Immuno-hemolytic anemia, also known as Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria(PCH).

Immunohemolytic Anemia: 
Immunohemolytic anemia is caused by antibodies that recognize red cells and lead to their premature destruction.

Immuno-hemolytic anemias are of 3 types:

  Antibody type Antigen on the RBC surface  Temperature
Warm agglutinin IgG Rh antigen 37°C or higher
Cold agglutinin IgM  I/i antigens 

30°C, usually (0-10°C)
Cold hemolysin IgG P antigen  Biphasic hemolysis (37°C)

Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria(PCH):

PCH is a cold hemolysin type of hemolysis caused by IgG autoantibodies (Donath Landsteiner antibodies) directed against the P blood group antigen and brings about complement-mediated haemolysis.

Donath Landsteiner antibody is different from that in cold agglutinin disease. The DL antibody, despite its association as a cold autoantibody, is a biphasic hemolysin. i.e., the antibody binds to RBC at colder temperature but hemolysis occurs at core temperature 37°C.

It presents as intravascular hemolysis and hemoglobinuria.

Most cases are seen in children following viral infections .

It may be seen in association with tertiary syphilis or as a complication of certain infections such as Mycoplasma pneumonia, flu, measles and mumps.

Blood transfusion is required for control of anemia. It is a self-limiting condition (recover within 1 month).

In PCH : The direct antiglobulin (Coombs) test will be positive for complement only. It is characterized by the presence of Donath-Landsteiner antibody. It is a unique antibody with anti-P specificity at 4°C. Hence, it binds to the RBC at 4°C. However, it causes complement-mediated lysis at 37°C.

Interpretation of direct Coombs test results

Condition Agglutination with
anti- IgG anti- C3
Warm AIHA + +
Drug-induced + +
PCH - +
Cold agglutinin disease (IgM) - +
PNH - -

 

Differences between PCH and PNH are tabulated below

Condition Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria (PCH)
Onset Chronic with acute exacerbations   Acute
Pathogenesis Complement-mediated destruction of CD59/55(–) RBCs Immune lysis of normal red cells
Diagnosis Flow cytometry to display a CD59(–) red cell population Test for Donath-Landsteiner antibody
Triggers  infections, alcohol, exercise, stress or  medications triggered by viral infection

questions.text: A diabetic patient diagnosed with Covid 19 infection on steroid therapy presented with a black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose and redness of the right eye. There is significant visual impairment. On examination, there is a blackish necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mucormycosis. 

Invasive Mucormycosis has recently emerged as a life-threatening complication of COVID-19 in India. It is an opportunistic infection seen even in mild to moderate COVID patients with strong predisposing factors like hyperglycemia/uncontrolled diabetes. Diabetic patients receiving corticosteroids/ immunosuppressants for COVID-19 treatment are exceptionally vulnerable to develop mucormycosis due to the risk of steroid-induced hyperglycemia.

MUCORMYCOSIS:

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection caused principally by species of rhizopus, mucor, and lichtheimia. Among them, the most prevalent species are Rhizopus oryzae and R. delemar. It is seen in patients with diabetes mellitus, leukemias, lymphomas, long-term corticosteroid use, severe burns, and immunodeficiencies.

The common clinical form is rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis in which there is an invasion of the blood vessels in the nasal cavity, eyes, and brain causing thrombosis, infarction, and necrosis. They invade tissues of patients with reduced host defense. From there, they enter the blood vessels and proliferate in the walls of blood vessels particularly paranasal sinuses and orbit. The blackish discoloration is due to arterial and venous thrombosis leading to gangrene.

Diagnosis- They can be stained with 10% potassium hydroxide and can be cultured.

On Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, they appear as grey-white colonies with a thick cottony, fluffy surface.

Under the microscope, they appear as nonseptate, irregularly branched broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium (a sac containing spores). 

The below image shows broad aseptate and irregularly branched hyphae seen in mucormycosis

Treatment: Surgical debridement and amphotericin B administration (1st line agent). Other antifungal agents used are isavuconazole and posaconazole.

Amphotericin B:

This is available in 3 forms

  • Amphotericin B deoxycholate- It is inexpensive but is highly toxic and has poor nervous system penetration
  • Liposomal amphotericin B- It has better nervous system penetration, better outcome than amphotericin B deoxycholate. It is very expensive.
  • Amphotericin B lipid complex- It is less nephrotoxic than amphotericin B deoxycholate but expensive.

Important side effects are:

  • Infusion-related toxicity- fever, chills, muscle spasms, vomiting, headache, and hypotension.
  • Nephrotoxicity- It is seen in nearly all patients treated with amphotericin B.
  • Liver damage
  • Seizures and arachnoiditis may develop after intrathecal therapy.

 

Other forms:

  • Pulmonary mucormycosis- It is the second commonest form and presents with fever, dyspnea, cough, and chest pain.
  • Cutaneous mucormycosis- It usually results after trauma or any penetrating injury to the skin. The infection can penetrate into fascia, muscle, and bone.
  • Gastrointestinal mucormycosis- It primarily occurs in premature neonates who have disseminated disease or necrotizing enterocolitis.
  • Disseminated mucormycosis- The infection from the primary site can disseminate to the brain, bones, mediastinum, etc.

questions.text: An ECG revealed the following finding. Which of the following drugs would be most likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution:
This ECG with a wide QRS complex with prolonged QT interval points towards the diagnosis of torsades de pointes. Sotalol is most likely to cause Torsades de pointes.

Torsades de pointes (French: twisting of points)-It is a life-threatening form of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia with rapid asynchronous complexes and an undulating baseline on ECG.

Acute management - Magnesium and Isoproterenol

Chronic management - Beta blockade and cardiac pacing

Related Pearl: Drugs causing QT prolongation and torsades de pointes

Drugs Associated with QT Prolongation and Torsades de Pointes:

Antiarrhythmics:

  • Sotalol
  • Amiodarone
  • Quinidine
  • Procainamide
  • Dofetilide
  • Ibutilide

Antimicrobials:

  • Levofloxacin
  • Ciprofloxacin
  • Gatifloxacin
  • Moxifloxacin
  • Clarithromycin
  • Erythromycin
  • Ketoconazole
  • Itraconazole
  • Rilpivirine

Antidepressants:

  • Amitriptyline
  • Desipramine
  • Imipramine
  • Doxepin
  • Fluoxetine
  • Sertraline
  • Venlafaxine

Antipsychotics:

  • Haloperidol
  • Droperidol
  • Quetiapine
  • Ziprasidone
  • Thioridazine

Others:

  • Cisapride
  • Sumatriptan
  • Zolmitriptan
  • Arsenic
  • Dolasetron
  • Methadone

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is brought to the emergency. On examination, his PR is 50 bpm,  BP is 80/60 mmHg, RR is 7 breaths/min and his temperature is 95 F. He has pin point pupils and is disoriented.  What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Opioid intoxication is the most probable diagnosis in the above given clinical scenario. Opioids include morphine, heroin, codeine, etc.

Opioid Overdose Symptoms:

  • Triad of coma, respiratory depression, and pinpoint pupils(miosis)
  • Hypotension
  • Bradycardia
  • Shallow breathing
  • Hypothermia

Characteristics of opioid toxicity:

  • Opioid intoxication toxidrome - respiratory and mental status depression, analgesia, miosis, orthostatic hypotension, nausea and vomiting, histamine release resulting in localized urticaria and bronchospasm, ileus secondary to decreased GI motility, and urinary retention secondary to increased vesical sphincter tone.
  • Miosis is not universally present from intoxication with every opioid; normal or even enlarged pupils have been documented secondary to diphenoxylate, meperidine, morphine, pentazocine, and propoxyphene toxicity.
  • Opioid-induced acute lung injury, previously known as non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema, is an uncommon complication associated with heroin overdose.
Opioid receptor Actions
mu

Analgesia

Sedation

Miosis

Respiratory depression

Cough suppression

Euphoria

Decreased GI motility
kappa

Analgesia

Sedation

Miosis

Decreased GI motility

Dysphoria

Hallucinations
delta

Analgesia

Antidepressant effect

Airway protection and ventilatory maintenance are the most important treatment steps for opioid intoxications, because respiratory depression is the major morbidity and the cause of essentially all the mortality.

  • After adequate ventilation is ensured, administer naloxone.
  • Single-dose activated charcoal can be administered in case opioid ingestion occured within one hour.

Opioid withdrawal symptoms (mnemonic- O MY WITHDRAWALS):

  • Mydriasis
  • Yawning
  • Weakness
  • Insomnia, irritability
  • Tremors, tachycardia
  • Hyperthermia, hypertension
  • Diarrhea
  • Rhinorrhoea
  • Apnoeic attacks
  • Weight loss
  • Anxiety
  • Lacrimation
  • Sweating

Related Pearl: Substances of abuse

Substance
Withdrawal symptoms
Intoxication features
Alcohol
Tremors, delirium, seizures
Blackouts, nystagmus and slurring of speech
BZD
Tremors, insomnia, anxiety
Lethargy and drowsiness.
Opioid/ Heroin
Diarrhea, yawning, mydriasis, lacrimation, piloerection, cold turkey phenomenon
Euphoria, depressed mental status, miosis, respiratory depression, constipation.
Nicotine/ Tobacco
Increased appetite
Shows a biphasic pattern. 
Early stimulatory symptoms of vomiting, hypertension and tachycardia. Later depressive symptoms of hypotension and bradycardia.
Cannabis
Irritability, sweating, tremors, decreased appetite
Increased appetite, euphoria, conjunctival injection, dry mouth, panic, synesthesia, impaired time perception, amotivational syndrome, run amok and flashbacks.
Amphetamine
Depressed mood, suicidal thoughts, unpleasant dreams
Acute: Sympathetic overactivity, paranoid hallucinatory syndrome, violent behavior, psychosis and diaphoresis.
Chronic: Runs & crashes, choreiform movements, tooth decay. Can resemble schizophrenia.
Cocaine
Depressed mood, suicidal thoughts
Acute: Sympathetic overactivity, agitation, euphoria, chest pain, seizures and mydriasis
Chronic: Cocaine psychosis (Magnan sign) and black pigmentation of the tongue.
LSD/ Haluccinogen
Nothing significant
Synesthesia, brisk tendon reflex, tachycardia, hypertension, panic, ataxia, visual hallucinations, euphoria and dysphoria.
Phencyclidine (PCP)
Nothing significant 
Tachycardia, hypertension, ataxia, hallucinations, violent behavior, dissociation, amnesia and nystagmus.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect regarding atrophic rhinitis?

choices.text: Klebsiella ozaenae is associated with primary atrophic rhinitis.
Sodium bicarbonate is not a component of kemicetine antiozaena solution
In Modified Young's operation, nostrils are partially closed.

questions.solution:
DNS causes unilateral atrophic rhinitis i.e. only on roomier side and in severe cases. 

In atrophic rhinitis/ozaena, ciliated columnar epithelium is lost and is replaced by stratified squamous epithelium. There is atrophy of seromucinous glands, venous blood sinusoids and nerve elements. Arteries in the mucosa, periosteum and bone show obliterating endarteritis. The bones of the turbinate undergoes resorption causing widening of nasal chambers.  

Clinical presentation - nasal obstruction, foul odor (merciful anosmia), crusting of the nasal passage, pale nasal mucosa, wide nasal turbinates, epistaxis

Etiology of atrophic rhinitis: 

Etiology of primary atrophic rhinitis:

  • Hereditary- Involves more than one member of a family
  • Endocrinal- More common in females, starts at puberty and regresses after menopause
  • Racial- More common in mongoloid and caucasian races
  • Nutritional deficiency- Vitamin A, D, iron deficiencies
  • Autoimmune- Antigens of the nasal mucosa
  • Organism- Klebsiella ozaenae

Etiology of secondary atrophic rhinitis:

  • Specific infections like syphilis, lupus, leprosy and, rhinoscleroma
  • Long-standing purulent sinusitis
  • Radiotherapy to nose
  • Excessive surgical removal of turbinates
  • Diphtheroids, Proteus vulgaris, Escherichia coli, staphylococci and streptococci

 

MEDICAL Treatment
Nasal irrigation
  • warm saline
  • alkaline solution composed of
    • sodium bicarbonate 1 part,
    • sodium biborate 1 part,
    • sodium chloride 2 parts in 280 mL of water
Local antibiotics

Kemicetine antiozaena solution containing 

  • Chloramphenicol,
  • Oestradiol and
  • Vitamin D2. 
Others 
  • 25% glucose in glycerine
  • Oestrodiol spray
  • Placental extract
  • Streptomycin
  • Potassium iodide

Avoid decongestants (Phenylephrine) which can worsen the already compromised blood supply to nasal mucosa in atrophic rhinitis.

SURGICAL Treatment
Young's operation both the nostrils are closed completely
Modified Young's operation both the nostrils are closed partially
Narrowing the nasal cavities  

 

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Atrophic Rhinitis

  • More common in females 
  • Usually starts at puberty
  • It is a bilateral condition
  • Symptoms:
    • Foul smell from the nose
    • Nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers due to large crusts filling nasal cavity
    • Epistaxis on removing of the crusts
    • Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements (merciful anosmia)
  • Signs:
    • Greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum
    • After removal of crusts, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates
    • Nasal mucosa appears pale

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presented with pain and redness in her right eye associated with severe right-sided headache for 2 days. O/E, there was conjunctival congestion, chemosis and her right Pupil was vertically oval and mid-dilated. Intraocular pressure: 64 mm Hg. The anterior chamber (AC) was shallow. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette is suggestive of a case of ACUTE CONGESTIVE GLAUCOMA/ ANGLE CLOSURE GLAUCOMA.

Acute primary angle-closure glaucoma

The term "angle closure" refers to the occlusion of the trabecular meshwork by the peripheral iris (iridotrabecular contact [ITC]), obstructing aqueous outflow.

Angle closure can be primary, when it occurs in an anatomically predisposed eye or secondary to another ocular or systemic factor.

Classification

  • Primary angle-closure suspect (PACS)
    • Gonioscopy shows posterior meshwork ITC in three or more quadrants but no PAS.
    • Intraocular pressure (IOP), optic disc, and visual field are normal.
    • No peripheral anterior synechiae (PAS) are seen
    • The risk of PACG at 5 years may be around 30%.
  • Primary angle closure (PAC)
    • Gonioscopy shows three or more quadrants of ITC with raised IOP and/or PAS or excessive pigment smudging on the TM.
    • Normal optic disc and field.
  • Primary angle-closure glaucoma (PACG)
    • ITC in three or more quadrants, with glaucomatous optic neuropathy.
    • Optic nerve damage from an episode of severe IOP elevation, such as acute angle closure, may not appear as typical glaucomatous cupping.

Risk factors

  • Age: The average age of relative pupillary block is about 60 years at presentation
  • Gender: Females are more commonly affected than males.
  • Race: Particularly prevalent in Far Eastern and Indian Asians.
  • Family history
  • Refraction: Eyes with "pure" pupillary block are typically hypermetropic.
  • Axial length: Short eyes tend to have a shallow anterior chamber (AC); eyes with nanophthalmos have a very short eye with a proportionally large lens and are at particular risk.

Symptoms: Pain, redness, photophobia, impaired vision, watering

Signs:

  • Corneal edema: colored halos
  • Conjunctiva: congestion, chemosis
  • IOP: elevated 40–70 mm Hg
  • AC very shallow
  • Pupil: vertically oval, mid-dilated
  • Angle: completely closed, Grade 0

Treatment:

  • Immediate: Intravenous mannitol, intravenous acetazolamide followed by oral dose, topical beta-blockers, brimonidine, latanoprost
  • Definitive: Laser peripheral iridotomy, filtration surgery

questions.text: A rice cultivation farmer brought his 16-month-old child to the OPD for routine immunisation. He has been adequately immunised until now. He has already received a measles vaccine during an SIA drive (supplementary immunisation activity) a few months back. What will you administer now?

choices.text: OPV booster, DPT booster and Vitamin A
OPV Booster, DPT booster, MR, JE and Vitamin A
OPV Booster, DPT booster, MR and Vitamin A

questions.solution:
OPV Booster, DPT booster, MR, JE and  Vitamin A should be given to the child.

The child should receive the routine doses of measles vaccine according to the schedule irrespective of the measles SIA dose. So, the second dose of the measles vaccine is also given.

JE is endemic in rural agricultural areas, often associated with rice cultivation and flood irrigation. Since this child comes from such an endemic area, JE vaccination should be given.

Vaccines to be given at 16months of age: OPV Booster, DPT booster, MR, Vitamin A and JE.

JE vaccine used to be given as a single dose in the endemic areas. JE second dose has been introduced under UIP in the endemic districts from April,13. The vaccine given under UIP is a live attenuated vaccine. A new Vero cell-derived inactivated JE vaccine is introduced in India under the IAP immunisation schedule. Two doses of JE vaccine are given now under both UIP and IAP.

Related Pearl: National Immunization Schedule (India)

questions.text: All of the following statements are TRUE regarding Trigeminal neuralgia EXCEPT?

choices.text: Carbamazepine is the drug of choice
Most commonly involves ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve
No objective signs of sensory loss

questions.solution:
Trigeminal neuralgia / Tic douloureux most commonly involves the second (V2) and/or third (V3) divisions of the trigeminal nerve territory. (ophthalmic V1 division is rarely involved)

It is characterized by unilateral lancinating facial pain, most commonly involving the second and/or third divisions of the trigeminal nerve territory.

Bilateral or early onset is associated with multiple sclerosis.

Unilateral trigeminal nerve compression can be due to the superior cerebellar artery.

Middle-aged and elderly persons are affected primarily, and more common in females. The pain usually lasts for a short time (seconds to minutes)  but may be so intense that the patient winces, hence the term tic.

The characteristic feature of trigeminal neuralgia is the presence of trigger zones, typically on the face, lips, or tongue. The patients usually report that tactile stimuli during activities such as washing the face, brushing the teeth, or exposure to a draft of air leads to excruciating pain.

Pain is repetitive, severe, and very brief. Physical signs are usually absent, although the spasms may make the patient wince and sit silently (tic douloureux). No objective signs of sensory loss.

Drug of choice-carbamazepine

Oxcarbazepine is an alternative to carbamazepine that has less bone marrow toxicity and is equally efficacious.

Other drugs used are lamotrigine, gabapentin and baclofen.

questions.text: Ilioinguinal nerve was injured inadvertently during direct inguinal hernia surgery. Which of the following is true regarding this condition ?

choices.text: Loss of sensation in the root of the penis
Numbness and paraesthesia along the anterolateral thigh
Loss of sensation in the skin of scrotum
Loss of sensation in the suprapubic area

questions.solution:
Loss of sensation in the root of the penis and adjacent part of the scrotum is suggestive of an injury to the ilioinguinal nerve. It is most commonly injured within the inguinal canal in open hernia repair due to traction or thermal injury.

OPTION B:

Meralgia paraesthetica which is caused by injury to the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve. The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is at risk of injury during prolonged pushing with hip flexion as the nerve is compressed under the inguinal ligament.

OPTION C : 

Injury to genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve results in loss of sensation in the skin of scrotum of males, and loss of sensation of the mons pubis and labia majora in females. 

OPTION D : 

The iliohypogastric nerve carries the sensory supply from the suprapubic area. Injury to this nerve within the inguinal canal rarely causes sensory disturbances, as the suprapubic area has a rich nerve supply from other sources too. If the nerve is severed above the anterior superior iliac spine, it can lead to the weakened posterior wall of the inguinal canal resulting in direct inguinal hernia.

questions.text:
Suitable cases for expectant management in case of placenta previa include:
  1. No active vaginal bleeding 
  2. Duration of pregnancy <37 wk
  3. Reactive NST
  4. Maternal Hb ≥10 g%
  5. Hematocrit value of at least 30%
questions.solution:
1,2,3,4 and 5 are suitable case for expectant management of placenta previa.

Risk factors for placenta previa

  • Multigravida
  • Age > 35 years
  • Smoking
  • Previous cesarean section or myomectomy
  • Abnormal placental size and lobes
  • Prior curettage

Clinical features of placenta previa:

  • Sudden-onset recurrent painless vaginal bleeding: First bleeding usually appears after the end of the second trimester or later and is usually mild and not fatal. This is called ‘Sentinel bleed’. 
  • The size of the uterus corresponds to gestational age. 
  • The uterus is relaxed, soft, no tenderness 
  • Floating head 
  • Fetal heart sound is present unless there is major separation and the patient is exsanguinated.
  • Slowing of fetal heart rate on pressing the head down into the pelvis which recovers promptly as pressure is relieved is suggestive of a low-lying placenta especially of posterior type: Stallworthy sign.

Degree of placenta previa:

There are four types of placenta previa depending upon the degree of extension of the placenta to the lower segment

  • Type—I (Low-lying): The major part of the placenta is attached to the upper segment and only the lower margin encroaches onto the lower segment but not up to the internal os.
  • Type—II (Marginal): The placenta reaches the margin of the internal os but does not cover it.
  • Type—III (Incomplete or partial central): The placenta covers the internal os partially (covers the
    internal os when closed but does not entirely do so when fully dilated).
  • Type—IV (Central or total): The placenta completely covers the internal os even after it is fully dilated.

Per-Vaginal Examination should not be done in suspected Placenta Previa, whereas it can be only done in the operation theatre with all the arrangements for C-section.

The image below shows the types of placenta previa.

Expectant management for placenta previa was advocated by Macafee and Johnson. The aim is to continue the pregnancy for fetal maturity without compromising maternal health. 

Prerequisites 

  • Availability of blood for transfusion whenever required 
  • Facilities for cesarean section should be available 24 h. 

Suitable cases for expectant management for placenta previa: 

  • Mother in good health (Hb ≥10 g%; hematocrit ≥30%) 
  • Duration of pregnancy <37 wk
  • No active vaginal bleeding 
  • Fetal well-being is assured (USG) 

Conduct of expectant treatment

  • Corticosteroids for fetal lung maturity if <34 wk
    • Betamethasone 12mg IM 24 hours apart for 2 doses or
    • Dexamethasone 6mg IM 12 hours apart for 4 doses
  • Bedrest 
  • Hb, Blood grouping and urine for protein 
  • Inspection of vulval pads, fetal surveillance with USG
  • Supplementary hematinics 
  • Rh Immunoglobin should be given to all Rh-negative (unsensitized) women
  • Use of tocolytics if there are uterine contractions.

The pregnancy is carried till 37 weeks as part of expectant management. During this time, if there is fetal distress or a bleeding episode, then terminate immediately.

Note - Cervical cerclage is not a part of expectant management

questions.text: A newborn is being assessed 5 minutes after birth. He is found to have a heart rate of 110bpm, coughs on stimulation, and has a strong cry. His limbs are well flexed, the body is pink, but extremities appear blue. The Apgar score for this newborn is ______
questions.solution:
The Apgar score for this newborn is 9.

In this baby:

  • Body pink, extremities blue: score 1
  • Heart rate, >100 beats/min: score 2
  • Coughs on stimulation, score 2
  • Well flexed limbs: score 2
  • Strong cry: score 2

Thus the total score is 9.

Apgar score is not used to guide resuscitation, and resuscitation must be initiated before the 1-minute score. The change of score at sequential time points following birth reflects how well the baby is responding to resuscitative efforts.

A total score of 10 indicates that the infant is in the best possible condition. An infant with a score of 0-3 requires immediate resuscitation.

Dr. Virginia Apgar MD, an American obstetrical anesthesiologist, for her invaluable invention of the Apgar score.

questions.text: An elder sibling is playing with his 2-year-old sister and he pulls up the child by holding hands. The child starts crying, does not use her arm, and does not let anybody touch it. What is the possible cause?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis is pulled elbow. The history of lifting the child by the forearm and later the child refusing to let anyone touch her hand is pointing towards the diagnosis of the pulled elbow. 

The mechanism underlying this deformity is the subluxation of the annular ligament over the radial head. Characteristically the child holds the elbow in extension with the forearm pronated. It is treated by fully supinating the forearm.

Related Pearl: Important conditions of the elbow:

         Condition    Description      

Tennis elbow

 Lateral epicondylitis involving common extensor origin.

Golfer's elbow

 Medial epicondylitis involving the common flexor-pronator origin.

Baseball pitcher's elbow

Damage to the bones or soft tissue attached around the elbow due to repeated vigorous throwing activities. Hypertrophy of the lower humerus and incongruity of the joint, or loose body formation and osteoarthritis.

Little leaguer's elbow

 Partial avulsion of the medial epicondyle.

Javelin thrower's elbow

 Avulsion of the tip of olecranon due to overarm action.

Student's elbow/Miner's elbow

 Olecranon bursitis.

Pulled elbow/Nurse maid's elbow

 Downward dislocation of the radial head from the annular ligament.

questions.text: Identify the skin condition shown in the image.
questions.solution:
In this image, a typical erythematous psoriatic plaque is shown with  silvery white scales. The site of predilection in psoriasis is usually extensor areas.

Other options:

  • Lichen planus: Presents with plane, polygonal, purple, pruritic, papules (5Ps)
  • Pemphigus: Presents with erosions on the skin and flaccid blisters
  • Pityriasis rubra pilaris: Presents with red follicular hyperkeratotic papules on trunk with islands of sparing.
